snippet: After a yearlong oil drilling moratorium, BP and other companies have intensified exploration and production in the Gulf of Mexico, and drilling will soon expand to Mexican and Cuban waters.
abstract: Deepwater drilling is regaining momentum in the Gulf of Mexico and around the world, despite a yearlong moratorium triggered by an explosion on an oil platform that killed 11 workers and sent millions of gallons of oil gushing into the gulf; analysts say the reason for resumption of such drilling is continuing demand for energy worldwide; Energy Department recently projected that gulf oil production would expand from 1.3 million barrels a day in 2011 to two million barrels a day by 2020.

byline.original: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS and JOHN M. BRODER
byline.contributor: Clifford Krauss reported from Houston and John M. Broder from Washington.

lead_paragraph: After a yearlong oil drilling moratorium, BP and other companies have intensified exploration and production in the Gulf of Mexico, and drilling will soon expand to Mexican and Cuban waters.

headline.seo: Deepwater Oil Drilling Returns to Gulf and Grows as Blast Fades
headline.main: Deepwater Oil Drilling Picks Up Again as BP Disaster Fades
headline.print_headline: Oil Drilling in the Gulf Rebounds As Prices Promote Exploration
